awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: US Forest Service Decisions and Innovations
awd_abstract_narration:
Effective public decision-making requires an evidence-based approach, and leading scientists frequently call for producing policy-relevant science, yet little is known about how government officials use science in their day-to-day work. This project will fill this gap by conducting a systematic analysis of use of science in thousands of decisions about environmental policy made at multiple levels of the US federal government. We focus on the contents of Environmental Impact Statements (EISs) prepared by the US Forest Service (USFS) under the National Environmental Policy Act. Providing a more detailed picture of how scientific information is used in government decision-making will enable government agencies to improve the processes through which they incorporate scientific information. At the same time, providing details of what types of scientific information are utilized in public decision-making processes will help scientists, universities, and funding agencies prioritize science that is policy-relevant. To forward these goals, the project will publish an index that will assist scientists in comparing the policy impact of different publications and will conduct outreach activities with environmental planners to help them understand the implications of the research.

This project will use web scraping and computational text analysis to collect and analyze the use of science in all USFS EISs produced between 2006 and 2018. These EISs record the scientific basis for at least 2,000 decisions made about public land management in a wide variety of contexts. The project has two objectives: (1) Understand what drives the inclusion of innovative scientific information (data, facts, evidence) in USFS EISs; and (2) Understand what drives the adoption of innovative scientific practices (operating procedures, protocols, norms) by USFS decision-makers preparing EISs. Using computational text analysis and machine learning tools, we will measure various aspects of the scientific content of each document such as citations, key concepts, and analytical practices. We will combine this information with publicly available data about the scientific information in each document, such as place of publication, employer of the scientists producing the document, extent of public participation in the document's preparation, and the government office using the scientific information. This analysis will help in understanding how characteristics of scientific information and characteristics of government offices influence how science is used in public decision-making processes.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project aimed to gather and analyze data about how science is used in government decision-making. We specifically focused on the implementation of the National Environmental Policy Act (NEPA) by the US Forest Service. NEPA requires all federal agencies to conduct an environmental impact assessment prior to initiating any major actions. These assessments are required to be conducted using scientific information and thus provide a window into how science is used to make government decisions, and the US Forest Service conducts more of these assessments than any other agency, making it a useful agency to study. The NEPA process has recently been subject to controversy since it is seen by some as a vital decision-making process that enables public participation in agency decision-making and systematizes the use of science in governmental processes, and by others as a time-consuing and litigation-prone barrier to achieving important public goals. 

 

We collected systematic information on all NEPA actions undertaken by the US Forest Service since 2006, when the agency began keeping detailed digital records, and developed open source software that enabled us to automatically extract reference and citation information from the digital files documenting these assessments. This data enabled us to systematically analyze US Forest Service decision-making processes and their relationship to science and public participation.

 

We found that, at least for the types of projects pursued by the US Forest Service, critics of NEPA have overstated their case. We found that most NEPA analyses are completed much faster than the high profile cases of years of delay which critics focus on and litigation is not very common. Second, by combining the NEPA data that was the major focus of this project with other administrative datasets we obtained from the US Forest Service, we found that other administrative processes, such as contracting, took as long or longer than NEPA processes, indicating that the slow pace of some projects is due not only to environmental analysis, but to a range of factors. These results have been widely discussed in the policy community.

 

Our second major set of findings focus on understanding the relationship between scientific analysis and decision-making in government agencies. We find that there are three major factors that influence how science is used in decision-making by government agencies: (1) the strategic design and use of administrative procedures by elected officials, (2) the differential capacity of actors to engage in the policy process, and (3) Discrepancies in stakeholders’ information provision and uptake. Furthermore, differences in agency mission, culture, and capacity, as well as the professional training of individual officials can play a major role in the uptake of scientific knowledge. We further test these theories by examining the ways in which government officials aim to influence decision-making, and find evidence that under some circumstances, government officials with different preferences for economic development and environmental conservation can influence the level of scientific analysis which an individual project receives. 

 

The software we developed to extract and analyze references have generated preliminary data. We have extracted more than 60,000 references from USFS NEPA documents and created measures that describe the age, novelty (first observed in the set of documents), scientific impact, and disciplinary diversity of the peer-reviewed references in a given NEPA document. We find that journals like Forest Ecology and Management, Journal of Wildlife Management, and Conservation Biology are among the most highly cited and that very few references come from social science journals. We expect to produce additional analyses of this data in the coming years.   

 

Finally, we collected the text and location of over two million public comments submitted to the USFS during NEPA comment periods. We are using this data to analyze four controversial public lands decisions, including the 2020 Alaska Roadless Rule. Preliminary analyses show that public comments come from individuals across the US and that the majority of public comments on these four projects are standardized form letters. Our work on public comments complements the research on scientific information; agencies weigh both in decision-making.
